newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Bargain hunters boost Australian stocks by end.
newsitem.headline: Bargain hunters boost Australian stocks by end.

text.p: The Australian share market closed higher on Tuesday, keeping a firm grasp on gains that had looked unlikely at the start of the day. By the close, the All Ordinaries index was up 9.5 points at 2228.7.
Brokers said bargain hunters had buoyed the bourse after an initial selldown, driven by weaker metals prices overnight, quickly petered out and investors went looking for value.
"We had solid buying this afternoon," said a Sydney broker.
"The selling dried up early and the bargain hunters were about. The leaders have been well marked down recently."
Turnover at A$633 million was solid rather than spectacular, with investors anticipating greater activity after the U.S. Federal Open Market Committee meets on Tuesday night.
"I would expect more action tomorrow after the FOMC meets tonight. Some are holding back (until then)," the broker said.
Oil and gas major Santos saw its shares jump to a six year high after announcing a new oil and gas find in Queenland, its second in the Cooper/Eromanga Basin in the past week.

Beverages group CC-Amatil, transport and logistics group Brambles and telecommunications, transport and healthcare group Mayne Nickless found support as investors targetted growth stocks after a flat few days for the industrial sector.
Falls just shaded rises, while about 36 percent of stocks traded remained steady.
